text: What's up outliers? Happy Monday, no trading today except for some futures action and even that's been really, really slow. The goal for the video today is to do a little bit of a look ahead on the market, what's coming up and just what the market looks like it's setting up as for the week, how I'm thinking about it at least. And then I want to walk you through four of my recent trades just to give you an idea of some of the things that I'm looking at, why I'm looking at them and how I'm fitting them into the portfolio. So that's the agenda. I do want to start with this, what you see in front of you here. For those that are familiar with the channel, you know that I have a stats background and I really enjoy conducting data analysis. It sounds kind of weird to say that out loud. It makes me sad for myself to a degree, but I genuinely do find this stuff interesting. I actually couldn't tell you why. And what I took a look at here is analyzing the average weekly return in spy for the past 15 years. When I compared it versus a short and I labeled it long, but that's a standard trading week. text: When I compared it versus a short and I labeled it long, but that's a standard trading week. So short is essentially if there's at least one day closed of the market. So this week Monday closed, if it's Monday, Tuesday closed, that would still fall into short. And then long is just standard. So Monday through Friday markets open. And a couple things jumped out of me here. The first thing is I actually thought both of these would be a little bit larger in terms of severity. And this highlighted a really interesting change in paradigm that I'm not used to seeing. And it's because if you think about it in the last 15 years, rather than that 15 year period, essentially being kicked off by a bear market 2007, 2008, 2009 kind of like that timeframe, that then just turned into a progressive nonstop bull market. It's actually a different snapshot shot. Now when we look at this stuff and it's pretty cool because we've had two bear markets. We've had one in 2020 when we saw that COVID crash. And even though that was a quick bear market that ended up being a positive year, it still was a bear market for like three days. And then the second was in 2022 when the market was down like 19.4. That was a really interesting year. So that starts to change a little bit of the data that we'll pick up. And it's actually kind of cool

And the reason why I sold a put spread is because rather than worrying about stopping out on the trade or setting some sort of stop for something like this that has pretty high movement, right? So if we look at the 5-day movement average five days is 12. And if we look at the 28, 17. So the probability of getting stopped out in something like this is really high for the way that I would trade. So here essentially, I was able to put on a 20 September 29, 28 put credit spread for 40 cents. So it's a dollar wide. And the reason why I stuck with the dollar wide versus widening them out is because of the edge I was able to derive from this because for a dollar wide credit spread neutral based on standard 30 delta short putt would be 33 cents is what I would need for like a for a neutrally expectant put credit spread. So here is able to get 40 cents. And when I modeled the 2 wide, the 5 wide, it didn't have the same edge that these did at the time that I put the trade on under 27th. So just let this baby ride.
